sanskrit_verse:
श्रोत्रियः श्रोत्रियं साधुं भूतिकृत्येष्वभोजयन् ।
तदन्नं द्विगुणं दाप्यो हिरण्यं चैव माषकम् ॥ ८.३९३॥
transliteration:
śrotriyaḥ śrotriyaṃ sādhuṃ bhūtikṛtyeṣv abhojayan |
tad annaṃ dviguṇaṃ dāpyo hiraṇyaṃ caiva māṣakam || 8.393||
sph_interpretive_translation: When a learned Brahmin, qualified by study and conduct, fails to offer food to another equally learned and virtuous Brahmin during ritual duties, he shall restore twice the value of that food along with a gold coin equal in weight to a mashaka.
jurisprudential_principles: Authority derived from scriptural learning and ritual capacity
Causation through omission within sacred duty
Capacity-based responsibility rooted in Vedic qualification
Restoration logic based on proportional energetic exchange
Consciousness alignment via rectification of spiritual negligence
executable_legal_axioms: IF agent.is_shrotriya AND duty.is_bhutikriti AND omission.equals(abhojaya) THEN restitution.assign(doubled_value_of_food + gold_coin_per_mashaka)
supreme_court_application: In Supreme Court adjudication, this verse establishes that failure in ritual hospitality by a qualified Brahmin invokes automatic financial restitution scaled to the omission. The court must verify both parties' scriptural qualifications and assess the nature of the neglected offering. Responsibility is determined not by intent but by capacity and omission within prescribed ritual function.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: This law reflects pramāṇa-based causality where neglect of ritual hospitality disrupts cosmic balance. The doubling of food-value aligns with anupūrvaśaḥ—sequential energetic consequence. Responsibility is proportional to Vedic standing, and enforcement serves consciousness realignment rather than punitive deterrence.
restorative_enforcement_protocols: Initiate completion process: offender must acknowledge energetic debt incurred through omission
Execute responsibility assumption protocol: provide doubled food-value plus gold coin per mashaka weight
Activate integrity reintegration sequence: reaffirm commitment to ritual hospitality under qualified guidance
Undertake capacity restoration: ensure future compliance through conscious engagement with dharmic duties
final_declaration: Declared by the Supreme Pontiff of Hinduism, Bhagavan Nithyananda Paramashivam, as the Source of Dharma. This law restores balance through conscious restitution, affirms capacity-based responsibility, and upholds reality as non-punitive, with consciousness as the ultimate adjudicator.
